csharp_simple:
1using System;
2using System.Collections.Generic;
3​
4namespace TechnicalIndicators
5{
6 /// <summary>
7 /// Williams Percent R (%R)
8 /// </summary>
9 /// <remarks>
10 /// A momentum indicator that measures overbought and oversold levels.
11 /// <list type="bullet">
12 /// <item><description>Similar to Stochastic Oscillator but inverted scale (0 to -100).</description></item>
13 /// <item><description>Formula: (HighestHigh - Close) / (HighestHigh - LowestLow) * -100.</description></item>
14 /// <item><description>Readings above -20 are overbought; below -80 are oversold.</description></item>
15 /// </list>
16 /// </remarks>
17 public class WilliamsPercentR
18 {
19 public int Period { get; }
20 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
21​
22 public WilliamsPercentR(int period = 14)
23 {
24 if (period <= 0)
25 throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException(nameof(period), "Period must be greater than 0");
26 Period = period;
27 }
28​
29 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
30 {
31 Values.Clear();
32 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
33 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
34​
35 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
36 {
37 if (i < Period - 1)
38 {
39 Values.Add(null);
40 continue;
41 }
42​
43 // Find Highest High and Lowest Low in lookback
44 decimal highestHigh = decimal.MinValue;
45 decimal lowestLow = decimal.MaxValue;
46​
47 for (int j = i - Period + 1; j <= i; j++)
48 {
49 if (candleList[j].High > highestHigh) highestHigh = candleList[j].High;
50 if (candleList[j].Low < lowestLow) lowestLow = candleList[j].Low;
51 }
52​
53 decimal range = highestHigh - lowestLow;
54 if (range == 0)
55 {
56 Values.Add(-50); // Default neutral value when range is 0
57 }
58 else
59 {
60 decimal r = ((highestHigh - candleList[i].Close) / range) * -100;
61 Values.Add(Math.Max(-100, Math.Min(0, r)));
62 }
63 }
64 }
65​
66 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period = 14)
67 {
68 var wr = new WilliamsPercentR(period);
69 wr.Calculate(candles);
70 return wr.Values;
71 }
72 }
73}
csharp_detailed:
1// =============================================================================
2// Logic Breakdown (WilliamsPercentR)
3// =============================================================================
4//
5// This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6// Williams %R indicator, developed by Larry Williams.
7// We explain *why* code is written this way and *how* data transforms
8// line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
9//
10// [Core Concepts]
11// 1. Williams %R - Momentum Oscillator
12// - Measures where the current close is relative to the high-low range
13// over a lookback period.
14// - Range: -100 to 0 (inverted scale compared to Stochastic).
15// - Closely related to Stochastic %K but with inverted formula.
16//
17// 2. Formula
18// - %R = ((HighestHigh - Close) / (HighestHigh - LowestLow)) × -100
19// - Interpretation:
20// - %R near 0: Close is near the high → strong bullish / overbought.
21// - %R near -100: Close is near the low → strong bearish / oversold.
22//
23// 3. Relationship to Stochastic %K
24// - Stochastic %K = (Close - LowestLow) / (HighestHigh - LowestLow) × 100
25// - Williams %R = ((HighestHigh - Close) / Range) × -100
26// - %R = -(100 - %K) = %K - 100 (mathematically equivalent)
27//
28// 4. Trading Signals
29// - Overbought: %R > -20 (close to 0).
30// - Oversold: %R < -80 (close to -100).
31// - Watch for divergences between %R and price.
32//
33// =============================================================================
34​
35using System;
36using System.Collections.Generic;
37​
38namespace TechnicalIndicators
39{
40 // =============================================================================
41 // Logic Explanation: Data Structure (CandleData)
42 // =============================================================================
43 //
44 // [Why] Standard OHLCV container for all indicators.
45 //
46 // [What] - High/Low: For finding HighestHigh and LowestLow.
47 // - Close: Current price to compare against range.
48 //
49 // [Who] All indicator classes.
50 //
51 // [Where] Stack-allocated record struct.
52 // =============================================================================
53 public readonly record struct CandleData(
54 DateTime Timestamp,
55 decimal Open,
56 decimal High,
57 decimal Low,
58 decimal Close,
59 long Volume
60 );
61​
62 // =============================================================================
63 // Logic Explanation: Indicator Class (WilliamsPercentR)
64 // =============================================================================
65 //
66 // [Why] Williams %R identifies overbought/oversold conditions and
67 // potential trend reversals.
68 // - Simple momentum measure.
69 // - Widely used since the 1970s.
70 //
71 // [What] This class:
72 // - Takes Period (default 14) for lookback window.
73 // - Outputs List<decimal?> with %R for each bar.
74 // - Returns null during warm-up phase.
75 //
76 // [Who] Mean-reversion traders, oscillator-based strategies.
77 //
78 // Why 'class'?
79 // - Mutable output list.
80 // =============================================================================
81 public class WilliamsPercentR
82 {
83 // -------------------------------------------------------------
84 // Logic Explanation: Indicator Configuration (Public Properties)
85 //
86 // [Why]
87 // Period determines lookback for high/low search.
88 //
89 // [What]
90 // - Period: Lookback window (typical: 14).
91 // - Values: Output %R list.
92 // -------------------------------------------------------------
93​
94 // -------------------------------------------------------------
95 // Variable Definition: Period
96 // public int Period { get; }
97 //
98 // [Role]
99 // Number of bars to search for HighestHigh and LowestLow.
100 //
101 // [Type Choice]
102 // int: Whole number. get-only: Immutable.
103 // -------------------------------------------------------------
104 public int Period { get; }
105​
106 // -------------------------------------------------------------
107 // Variable Definition: Output Container
108 // public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
109 //
110 // [Role]
111 // Stores Williams %R for each candle (-100 to 0).
112 // null = warm-up phase.
113 //
114 // [Type Choice]
115 // decimal?: Nullable for incomplete windows.
116 // -------------------------------------------------------------
117 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
118​
119 // =============================================================================
120 // IPO: Constructor (WilliamsPercentR)
121 // =============================================================================
122 //
123 // [Input]
124 // - period: int - Lookback period. Default = 14.
125 //
126 // [Process]
127 // - Validate period.
128 // - Store.
129 //
130 // [Output]
131 // - Initialized WilliamsPercentR instance.
132 // =============================================================================
133 public WilliamsPercentR(int period = 14)
134 {
135 // -------------------------------------------------------------
136 // Logic Step 1: Validate Period
137 //
138 // [Decision]
139 // Is period <= 0?
140 //
141 // [True Branch: Invalid]
142 // Throw exception.
143 //
144 // [False Branch: Valid]
145 // Continue.
146 // -------------------------------------------------------------
147 if (period <= 0)
148 throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException(nameof(period), "Period must be greater than 0");
149​
150 Period = period;
151 }
152​
153 // =============================================================================
154 // IPO: Calculate (Main Processing Method)
155 // =============================================================================
156 //
157 // [Input]
158 // - candles: IEnumerable<CandleData> - Time-ordered market data.
159 //
160 // [Process]
161 // For each bar i:
162 // 1. If i < Period - 1: Output null (warm-up).
163 // 2. Find HighestHigh and LowestLow over past Period bars.
164 // 3. Compute %R = ((HighestHigh - Close) / Range) × -100.
165 // 4. Clamp to [-100, 0] for safety.
166 //
167 // [Output]
168 // - (side effect) Values list populated.
169 // =============================================================================
170 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
171 {
172 // -------------------------------------------------------------
173 // Logic Step 1: Clear Previous Results
174 //
175 // [Why]
176 // Enables instance reuse.
177 // -------------------------------------------------------------
178 Values.Clear();
179​
180 // -------------------------------------------------------------
181 // Logic Step 2: Materialize Enumerable
182 //
183 // [Why]
184 // Need indexed access for lookback.
185 // -------------------------------------------------------------
186 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
187​
188 // -------------------------------------------------------------
189 // Logic Step 3: Empty Data Guard
190 // -------------------------------------------------------------
191 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
192​
193 // -------------------------------------------------------------
194 // Logic Step 4: Main Loop
195 //
196 // [Why]
197 // Compute Williams %R for each bar.
198 //
199 // [How]
200 // For each bar, scan the previous Period bars to find
201 // HighestHigh and LowestLow, then apply formula.
202 //
203 // [Visual]
204 // Period = 5, at i = 6:
205 // Scan bars 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
206 // Find highest High, lowest Low
207 // %R = ((HH - Close[6]) / (HH - LL)) × -100
208 // -------------------------------------------------------------
209 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
210 {
211 // -------------------------------------------------------------
212 // Logic Step 4.1: Warm-Up Check
213 //
214 // [Decision]
215 // Is i < Period - 1?
216 //
217 // [True Branch: Warm-Up]
218 // Not enough bars. Output null.
219 //
220 // [False Branch: Ready]
221 // Proceed to computation.
222 // -------------------------------------------------------------
223 if (i < Period - 1)
224 {
225 Values.Add(null);
226 continue;
227 }
228​
229 // -------------------------------------------------------------
230 // Variable Definition: HighestHigh and LowestLow
231 //
232 // [Role]
233 // Track the extreme prices over the lookback window.
234 // Initialized to extreme opposite values to ensure any
235 // real price will update them.
236 //
237 // [Type Choice]
238 // decimal.MinValue / MaxValue: Guaranteed to be replaced.
239 // -------------------------------------------------------------
240 decimal highestHigh = decimal.MinValue;
241 decimal lowestLow = decimal.MaxValue;
242​
243 // -------------------------------------------------------------
244 // Logic Step 4.2: Find HighestHigh and LowestLow
245 //
246 // [Why]
247 // Scan the window [i - Period + 1, i] to find extremes.
248 //
249 // [How]
250 // Loop j from window start to i (inclusive).
251 // Compare each High and Low to current extremes.
252 //
253 // [Visual]
254 // Period = 3, i = 4:
255 // Window: bars 2, 3, 4
256 // j=2: H=105, L=95
257 // j=3: H=108, L=100
258 // j=4: H=106, L=98
259 // HighestHigh = 108, LowestLow = 95
260 // -------------------------------------------------------------
261 for (int j = i - Period + 1; j <= i; j++)
262 {
263 if (candleList[j].High > highestHigh)
264 highestHigh = candleList[j].High;
265 if (candleList[j].Low < lowestLow)
266 lowestLow = candleList[j].Low;
267 }
268​
269 // -------------------------------------------------------------
270 // Logic Step 4.3: Compute Range
271 //
272 // [Why]
273 // Range = HighestHigh - LowestLow.
274 // Used as denominator in %R formula.
275 // -------------------------------------------------------------
276 decimal range = highestHigh - lowestLow;
277​
278 // -------------------------------------------------------------
279 // Logic Step 4.4: Compute %R
280 //
281 // [Decision]
282 // Is range == 0?
283 //
284 // [True Branch: Flat Market]
285 // All bars have identical High and Low.
286 // No meaningful %R. Convention: Output -50 (midpoint).
287 //
288 // [False Branch: Normal Case]
289 // %R = ((HighestHigh - Close) / Range) × -100
290 // Clamp to [-100, 0] for safety (though should naturally fall there).
291 //
292 // [Visual]
293 // HighestHigh = 110, LowestLow = 100, Close = 106
294 // Range = 10
295 // %R = ((110 - 106) / 10) × -100
296 // = (4 / 10) × -100
297 // = 0.4 × -100
298 // = -40
299 // Interpretation: Close is 40% below the high.
300 // -------------------------------------------------------------
301 if (range == 0)
302 {
303 Values.Add(-50);
304 }
305 else
306 {
307 decimal r = ((highestHigh - candleList[i].Close) / range) * -100;
308​
309 // Clamp to valid range [-100, 0]
310 // In normal market data this should always be within range,
311 // but numerical edge cases might push it slightly outside.
312 Values.Add(Math.Max(-100, Math.Min(0, r)));
313 }
314 }
315 }
316​
317 // =============================================================================
318 // IPO: Static Calculate (Convenience Wrapper)
319 // =============================================================================
320 //
321 // [Input]
322 // - candles: IEnumerable<CandleData> - Market data.
323 // - period: int - Lookback period (default 14).
324 //
325 // [Process]
326 // 1. Instantiation: Create WilliamsPercentR instance.
327 // 2. Execution: Call Calculate().
328 // 3. Extraction: Return Values.
329 //
330 // [Output]
331 // - List<decimal?> containing Williams %R for each bar.
332 //
333 // [Why Static?]
334 // One-liner usage:
335 // var wr = WilliamsPercentR.Calculate(candles, 14);
336 // =============================================================================
337 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period = 14)
338 {
339 // 1. Instantiation
340 // [Why: Setup with validated period]
341 var wr = new WilliamsPercentR(period);
342​
343 // 2. Execution
344 // [Why: Compute %R for all bars]
345 wr.Calculate(candles);
346​
347 // 3. Extraction
348 // [Why: Return oscillator values]
349 return wr.Values;
350 }
351 }
352}
python_simple:
1class WilliamsPercentR:
2 """
3 Williams %R
4 """
5 def __init__(self, period=14):
6 self.period = period
7 self.values = []
8​
9 def calculate(self, candles):
10 self.values.clear()
11 if not candles: return
12​
13 for i in range(len(candles)):
14 if i < self.period - 1:
15 self.values.append(None)
16 continue
17
18 highs = []
19 lows = []
20 for j in range(i - self.period + 1, i + 1):
21 highs.append(float(candles[j]['high']))
22 lows.append(float(candles[j]['low']))
23
24 hh = max(highs)
25 ll = min(lows)
26 c = float(candles[i]['close'])
27
28 rng = hh - ll
29 if rng == 0:
30 self.values.append(-50.0)
31 else:
32 r = ((hh - c) / rng) * -100.0
33 # Clamp between -100 and 0
34 val = max(-100.0, min(0.0, r))
35 self.values.append(val)
36​
37def calculate(candles, period=14):
38 obj = WilliamsPercentR(period)
39 obj.calculate(candles)
40 return obj.values
python_detailed:
1# =============================================================================
2# Logic Breakdown (WilliamsPercentR)
3# =============================================================================
4#
5# This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6# Williams %R.
7# We explain *why* code is written this way and *how* data transforms
8# line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
9#
10# [Core Concepts]
11# 1. Inverse Stochastic
12# - Implementation creates a "Stochastic" oscillator but flips the scale.
13# - Instead of 0 to 100, it runs from -100 to 0.
14# - 0 is the "Roof" (Highest High).
15# - -100 is the "Floor" (Lowest Low).
16#
17# 2. Buying/Selling Pressure
18# - If price closes near the High (0 to -20), Bulls are in control.
19# - If price closes near the Low (-80 to -100), Bears are in control.
20#
21# [Formula]
22# Range = Highest High - Lowest Low
23# Distance from High = Highest High - Close
24# %R = (Distance from High / Range) * -100
25#
26# =============================================================================
27​
28# -------------------------------------------------------------
29# Type-Level Explanation: WilliamsPercentR (class)
30#
31# [Why] To measure momentum by comparing close prive to the recent range.
32# [What] Momentum Oscillator (-100 to 0).
33# [How] Calculates the position of the current close relative to the highest high of the lookback period, scaled to -100 to 0.
34# [Who] Larry Williams (1973).
35# [Where] Heap (Class instance).
36# -------------------------------------------------------------
37class WilliamsPercentR:
38​
39 # -------------------------------------------------------------
40 # Logic Explanation: Indicator Configuration (Public Properties)
41 #
42 # [Why]
43 # Define the inputs and outputs.
44 #
45 # [What]
46 # - period: Lookback window (Standard 14).
47 # - values: Resulting %R values.
48 # -------------------------------------------------------------
49​
50 def __init__(self, period=14):
51 # -------------------------------------------------------------
52 # Logic Step 1: Validation
53 # -------------------------------------------------------------
54 if period <= 0:
55 raise ValueError("period")
56
57 # -------------------------------------------------------------
58 # Variable Definition: period
59 # [Role] Rolling window size.
60 # [Type Choice] Integer.
61 # -------------------------------------------------------------
62 self.period = period
63
64 # -------------------------------------------------------------
65 # Variable Definition: values
66 # [Role] Output storage.
67 # -------------------------------------------------------------
68 self.values = []
69​
70​
71 # =============================================================================
72 # IPO: calculate
73 # =============================================================================
74 #
75 # [Input]
76 # - candles: List[dict] - OHLCV Data.
77 #
78 # [Process]
79 # 1. Slide a window of size N.
80 # 2. Find Highest High and Lowest Low in that window.
81 # 3. Calculate where the Close sits relative to the High.
82 # 4. Normalize to -100 scale.
83 #
84 # [Output]
85 # - None.
86 # =============================================================================
87 def calculate(self, candles):
88 # -------------------------------------------------------------
89 # Logic Step 1: Cleanup
90 # [How] Clear the values list.
91 # -------------------------------------------------------------
92 self.values.clear()
93
94 # -------------------------------------------------------------
95 # Logic Step 2: Empty Check
96 # -------------------------------------------------------------
97 if len(candles) == 0:
98 return
99​
100 # -------------------------------------------------------------
101 # Logic Step 3: Main Loop
102 # [Why] Process each candle chronologically.
103 # [How] Iterate through the candle list using a for-loop.
104 # -------------------------------------------------------------
105 for i in range(len(candles)):
106
107 # -------------------------------------------------------------
108 # Logic Step 4: Window Check
109 #
110 # [Decision]
111 # Do we have N candles yet?
112 #
113 # [True Branch: Waiting]
114 # Append None.
115 #
116 # [False Branch: Ready]
117 # Begin Calculation.
118 #
119 # [How] Check if loop index 'i' is less than 'period - 1'.
120 # -------------------------------------------------------------
121 if i < self.period - 1:
122 self.values.append(None)
123 continue
124​
125 # -------------------------------------------------------------
126 # Logic Step 5: Find Extremes (Min/Max)
127 #
128 # [Why]
129 # Determine the "playing field" (Range) for the recent period.
130 #
131 # [How]
132 # Iterate through the sub-window [i - period + 1 : i].
133 # Track Max High and Min Low.
134 # -------------------------------------------------------------
135 highest_high = float('-inf')
136 lowest_low = float('inf')
137
138 for j in range(i - self.period + 1, i + 1):
139 if candles[j]['high'] > highest_high:
140 highest_high = candles[j]['high']
141 if candles[j]['low'] < lowest_low:
142 lowest_low = candles[j]['low']
143​
144 # -------------------------------------------------------------
145 # Logic Step 6: Calculation
146 #
147 # [Why]
148 # Compute the %R value.
149 #
150 # [How]
151 # 1. Calculate Range (High - Low).
152 # 2. Handle Zero Range (Division by Zero prevention).
153 # 3. Apply Formula.
154 #
155 # [Visual]
156 # High = 100, Low = 50, Close = 90
157 # Range = 50
158 # Dist from High = 100 - 90 = 10
159 # %R = (10 / 50) * -100 = -20 (Near Top)
160 # -------------------------------------------------------------
161 rng = highest_high - lowest_low
162
163 if rng == 0:
164 # Flat line scenario: Price hasn't moved (High=Low=Close).
165 # Conventionally return mid-point or top.
166 # Here we choose -50 (Neutral).
167 self.values.append(-50)
168 else:
169 # Formula: ((High - Close) / Range) * -100
170 # Note the negative sign multiply.
171 # If Close == High: Numerator is 0 -> Result 0.
172 # If Close == Low: Numerator is Range -> Result -100.
173 r = ((highest_high - candles[i]['close']) / rng) * -100
174
175 # -------------------------------------------------------------
176 # Logic Step 7: Clamping
177 #
178 # [Why]
179 # Floating point errors can sometimes result in -100.0000001
180 # or 0.0000001.
181 #
182 # [How]
183 # Clamp between -100 and 0.
184 # -------------------------------------------------------------
185 self.values.append(max(-100, min(0, r)))
186​
187​
188# =============================================================================
189# Static Wrapper Function
190# =============================================================================
191#
192# [Why] Functional interface.
193# -------------------------------------------------------------
194def calculate(candles, period=14):
195 # 1. Instantiation
196 # [Why: Setup state]
197 wr = WilliamsPercentR(period)
198
199 # 2. Execution
200 # [Why: Process data]
201 wr.calculate(candles)
202
203 # 3. Extraction
204 # [Why: Return clean result]
205 return wr.values
